@axrdb OK so your issue is the `statement_timeout` setting, which can be set either on your Postgres server (not in Airflow) , in your sessions, and possibly with environment variables on the client. There are a few ways to change it.
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/config-setting.html
First is using postgresql.conf file setting in the data directory on Postgres server. If you don't have server access, or don't want to make a global setting that will affect all queries then don't use this.

You can also set it in your session using something like (in milliseconds)
`set statement_timeout to 100000`
You could add that at the beginning of your SQL query being passed in the `sql` parameter for the `PostgresToGoogleCloudStorageOperator` and see if that works. 

To set it as environment variable on the client:
https://dba.stackexchange.com/a/1376/10866
You could set that permanently on the Airflow server, probably a good option.


There is also an `options` parameter available in the psycopg python package that Airflow uses for connections to Postgres. `options` will pass through any of a range of command line parameters to Postgres. 
The syntax _would_ be something like this:
options='-c statement_timeout=100000'
Unfortunately the PostgresHook doesn't allow for this parameter. The only options are the ones in conn_args, and certain extra ones allowed in the conn.extra field, including keepalives_idle . see:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/hooks/postgres_hook.py#L41

In the meantime, you could modify the hook to allow for `statement_timeout` in the conn.extra field. You could do it as a plugin for both the hook & operator, or fork, patch and contribute a pull request. I recommend creating a separate Jira ticket and issue for this, as it doesn't relate to this thread.
Allowing options could be useful for other parameters too, but of course your Postgres user would have to have appropriate permission to set them.

To be clear, keepalives_idle has nothing to do with your statement_timeout issue.

Tested the PR with a real Redshift cluster and confirmed that it worked.
It would be better if it was documented that the header is output into only the first file and users have to specify `PARALLEL OFF` to unload_options if they wants to load the output files back to Redshift correctly.

def delete_ghost_dags():
    dagbag = DagBag()
    dagbag_dag_ids = dagbag.dags.keys()
    logging.info(f'DagBag: {dagbag_dag_ids}')

    database_dags = session.query(DagModel).all()
    database_dag_ids = {d.dag_id for d in database_dags}
    logging.info(f'DagModel: {database_dag_ids}')

    for dag_id in database_dag_ids:

            delete_dag(dag_id)

    python_callable=delete_ghost_dags,
    dag=dag)
